subsection.title: Impulse as an Area

sidebyside.p: When you hit a baseball, you change direction and magnitue of the momentum of the ball in a very short duration of time. The change in momentum is caused by the force from the bat acting on the ball during the time they were in contact with each other.

If you look at the magnitude of the force on the ball, it will be initially zero till contact occurs, will increase as the bat crushes into the ball, and then, will decrease to zero as the ball leaves the bat. The stronger the force and/or the longer the force acts on the ball, the greater the change in the momentum of the ball.

subsection.p:
Impulse
That is, both the magnitude of the force and the time are important for causing a change in momentum. For this purpose, we define impulse, \vec J, during an infintesimal interval \Delta t by product of the force \vec F and the interval.
\vec J = \vec F \;\Delta t.

sidebyside.p:
For constant force \vec F_0, such as weight, impulse over a finite interval t_1\le t \le t_2 will be
\vec J = \vec F_0 \;(t_2 - t_1).

subsection.p:
If force is changing with time, as for example the force shown in , we will need to integrate \vec F(t) with respect to time t, or, work with area under the curve of the components of force versus time. Thus, impulse is formally defined by the following conceptual integral
\vec J = \int_{t_1}^{t_2}\vec F(t) \;dt\ \ \ (\text{Calculus/Formal Defintion}).
The Cartesian components of impulse will be integrals that you can perform from given funtions F_x(t), F_y(t), F_z(t).
J_i = \int_{t_1}^{t_2}\vec F_i(t) \;dt\ \ \ (i = x, y, z).
Previously, we have seen that another way to look at integrals is area under the curve. Thus, J_x during interval t_1\le t \le t_2 will be area between F_x(t) and F_x=0 when you plot F_x versus t.
J_i = \text{area under }F_i \text{ vs }t\text{ plot.}\ \ \ (i=x,y,z)
From the components (J_x, J_y, J_z), we can obtain the mangitude and direction of impulse as we do for any other vector quantity.

example.title: Impulse from the Area under F versus t

statement.p: The impulse of a baseball hit can be well-approximated by a hat-shaped curve as shown in . The direction of the force during the hit is nearly constant, in the direction from the bat towards the ball. From the given values on the graph find the magnitude of the impulse on the ball.

solution.p: Since direction of the force does not change, we can take that direction to be direction of positive x axis. In this case, J_y=J_z=0, and magnitude J = J_x.

sidebyside.p:
Therefore, we can compute the magnitude of impulse from the area under the curve of magnitude F versus t. The area is area of triangle, whose formula is
A = \dfrac{1}{2}\times \text{ base }\times \text{height}.

solution.p:
We also notice that the unit of time is in milli-sec, which we will express in seconds. Therefore, we get
J = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 70\text{ N}\times 200\times 10^{-3}\text{ s} = 7.0\text{ N.s}.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Impulse as an Integral
subsection.p: Consider an interval t=t_i to t=t_f during which we wish to compute the impulse of a force \vec F , whose direction is fixed in time, for simplicity. Here, we will show how the formula for the magnitude of impulse is derived.

Let us divide the interval into N subintervals: (t_0=t_i, t_1), (t_1, t_2), (t_2, t_3), \cdots, (t_{N-2}, t_{N-1}), and (t_{N-1}, t_N=t_f). For simplicity, let the intervals be of equal length in time, \Delta t,
\Delta t = \dfrac{t_f - t_i}{N}.

figure.caption: The impulse of a force over an interval (t_i, t_f) can be computed by dividing the interval into a large number of subintrevals, computing the magnitude of impulses for each subinterval, and then adding them up. During the subinterval (t_{k-1}, t_{k}) , the magnitude of force at the ends of the interval are F_{k-1} and F_{k} respectively, whose average is denoted by F_{k}^{\text{av}}.

subsection.p:
Now, let us compute the impulse magnitude J_k in the k^{\text{th}} subinterval. Let the magnitude of the force at the ends of this subinterval be F_{k-1} and F_{k} . If N is large enough, then F_{k-1} and F_{k} will be almost the same, and therefore, we can get a good approximation of impulse magnitude J_k by using the average force in the subinterval as
J_k \approx F_{k}^{\text{av}}\, \Delta t
We now add up impulses from every subinterval to get the impulse over the original interval.
J \approx \sum_{k=1}^{N} \, F_{k}^{\text{av}}\, \Delta t.
By increasing N as large as we like, we can make this aproximation as accurate as we are happy with. The limit N \rightarrow \infty is said to be the exact value, which is represented by the integral sign.
J = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, F(t) dt.
If we are dealing with a force whose magnitude as well as direction changes, then we will work with one component at a time. The same procedure as above will give us the components of the impulse vector.
\amp J_x = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, F_x(t) dt, \amp J_y = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, F_y(t) dt, \amp J_z = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, F_z(t) dt.
From (J_x, J_y, J_z) you can compute the magnitude and direction of the impulse in a usual way.

example.title: (Calculus) Impulse of a Force Varying in Time Given as a Function of Time

statement.p: A train is pulled by another train with increasing force magnitude for a total duration of 5\text{ sec} with the direction of the force unchanged. The magnitude of the force is given to be F(t) = 60\,t^2 + 2000 in units of \text{N}. What is the impulse magnitude?

solution.p:
Since direction of force is unchanging, we take that direction to be x axis. This will make magnitude J equal to J_x. That is, we can just integrate magnitude of force to obtain the answer.
J \amp = J_x = \int\, F_x(t) dt = \int\, F(t) dt \amp = \int_0^5 \left( 60\,t^2 + 2000 \right)\, dt \amp = \left( \dfrac{1}{3}\times 60\times 5^3 + 2000\times 5 \right) = 12,500\, \text{N.s}

subsection.title: Net Impulse
subsection.p:
Impulses from different forces add vectorially. Suppose force \vec F_1 acts for a time \Delta t_1 and \vec F_2 for a time \Delta t_2, then the net impulse \vec J_{\text{net}} will be the vector sum of the impulses \vec J_1 and \vec J_2 of the two forces.
\vec J_{\text{net}} = \vec J_{1} +\vec J_{2},
which must be evaluated as vector additions that you have learned in previous chapters. You can, of course, extend this to any number of forces in an obvious way.

sidebyside.p: A box is on a level surface. A force of magnitude 3\text{ N} acts on the box in the direction towards the East for 10\text{ sec} and another force of magnitude 8\text{ N} acts on the box in the direction towards the North for 5\text{ sec}.

statement.p: What are the magnitude and direction of the net impulse?

answer.p: 50\text{ N.s}, 53.1^{\circ} is the counterclockwise angle from the positive x axis.

solution.p:
Let us work this problem out analytically. (You could just as easily do it graphically.) Let positive x axis be towards East and the positive y axis towards North. then, we find the following for the two impulse vectors.
\amp J_{1x} = 3\times 10 = 30\text{ N.s},\ \ J_{1y} = 0, \amp J_{2x} = 0\ \ J_{2y} = 8\times 5 = 40\text{ N.s}.
Adding these vectorially we get the components of the net impulse
\amp J_x^{\text{net}} = J_{1x} +J_{2x} = 30 + 0 = 30\text{ N.s}, \amp J_y^{\text{net}} = J_{1y} +J_{2y} = 0 + 40 = 40\text{ N.s}.
This gives the following for the magnitude and angle with respect to the x axis.
\amp J_{\text{net}} = \sqrt{30^2 + 40^2} = 50\text{ N.s}, \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{40}{30}\right) = 53.1^{\circ}.
We use the angle value and the quadrant of (J_x,\, J_y) to interpret the direction. Here, since (30,\, 40) is in the first quadrant, the angle 53.1^{\circ} is the counterclockwise angle from the positive x axis.

exercise.title: Find Maximum Force from Given Impulse and Force Graph

sidebyside.p: The graph shows a hat-shaped function for the magnitude of a force as a function of time. By observing change in the momentum of the body, it was estimated that the impulse of the force is 10.0\text{ N.s}. What is the value of F_\text{max}?

hint.p: Equate the area under the curve to the impulse.

solution.p:
First we find an expression for the impulse from area under the given graph. Then, we equate it to find an equation in the unknown F_\text{max}. We also convert the unit of time to sec from the msec given in the graph. From the graph we get
J = \dfrac{1}{2}\, 0.200\, F_\text{max} = 0.1\, F_\text{max}.
Thus,
0.1\, F_\text{max} = 10.0\text{ N.s}.
This gives F_\text{max} = 100\text{ N}.

exercise.title: Impulse from Force Component Graphs in a Two-dimensional Situation

statement.p: The graph shows the x component of a force as a function of time. At t = 0, the x and y components of the momentum of the body upon which this force acts had the values p_x = 10\text{ kg.m/s} and p_y = -20\text{ kg.m/s}. Find the magnitude and direction of the momentum at t = 200\text{ ms}.

hint.p: Work out the x and y components separately.

answer.p: 6.32\text{ N.s}, 72^{\circ} clockwise from negative x axis

solution.p:
The area under the curves gives us the components of impulse.
J_x \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 100 \times 0.08 + (-50)\times 0.12 = -2\text{ N.s}, J_y \amp = -\dfrac{1}{2}\times 50 \times 0.04 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times 50 \times 0.04 + 50\times 0.12 = 6\text{ N.s}.
Therefore, the magnitude of impluse is
J = \sqrt{J_x^2 + J_y^2} = \sqrt{2^2 + 6^2} = 6.32\text{ N.s}.
Angle with x axis is
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \frac{6}{-2}\right) = -72^\circ.
Since point (-2,6) is in the second quadrant, the diration is 72^\circ clockwise from the negative x axis.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Impulse of a Sinusoidally Varying Force

statement.p: The time dependence of a sinusoidally varying force can be written as a sine or cosine of time. For instance, when an electron is illuminated by a monochromatic light, the force on the electron varies as a cosine or sine function or a combination thereof.

Suppose the force on an electron at some instant t has the following form with respect to a coordinate system, \vec F = A \cos (2\pi f t)\, \hat i + B \sin(2\pi f t)\, \hat j,
where \hat i and \hat j are the unit vectors along the x and y axes respectively, A and B are some constants, and f is also a constant frequency.
What will be the magnitude and direction of the impulse on the electron during an interval t=0 to t=T for the case A = B ?

hint.p: Find the components J_x and J_y

answer.p: \dfrac{A}{\pi f}\left|\sin(\pi f T) \right| , direction \pi f T \mod 2\pi .

solution.p:
We can find the components of the impulse vector and then write the full impulse vector using the components and the unit vectors.
J_x \amp = \int_0^T\, A \cos (2\pi f t)\, dt = \dfrac{A}{2\pi f}\, \sin (2\pi f T), J_y \amp = \int_0^T\, A \sin (2\pi f t)\, dt = -\dfrac{A}{2\pi f}\, \left[ \cos (2\pi f T) - 1 \right].
Therefore, using unit vectors, the impulse vector is
\vec J = J_x\, \hat i + J_y\, \hat j,
from which we can get the magnitude to be
J \amp = \sqrt{J_x^2 + J_y^2}, \amp = \dfrac{A}{2\pi f} \sqrt{2-2\cos(2\pi f T)}, \amp = \dfrac{A}{2\pi f} \sqrt{4\sin^2(\pi f T)}, \amp = \dfrac{A}{\pi f}\left|\sin(\pi f T) \right|,
and the angle for the line
\theta \amp = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{J_y}{J_x} \right), \amp = -\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{\cos(2\pi f T) - 1}{\sin(2\pi f T)} \right), \amp = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2\sin^2(\pi f T)}{2\sin(\pi f T)\cos(\pi f T)} \right), \amp = \tan^{-1}\left(\tan(\pi f T) \right) = \pi f T,
where the direction will be based on interpreting this angle mod\ 2\pi.
